editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Or, when women go to law, the devil is full of business.
A new tragicomedy. The true and perfect copy from the original. As it was approvedly well acted by her majesty's servants.
div.quote: Non quam diu, sed quam bene.
div.p: London, printed by A. m. for John Grismand, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's alley at the sign of the gunne.. 1623.

div.head: To the right worthy , and all-accomplisht gentleman, sir Thomas Finch, knight baronet.
div.p: Sir, let it not appear strange, that I do aspire to your patronage. Things that taste of any goodness, love to be sheltered near goodness: nor do I flatter in this (Which I hate) only touch at the original copy of your virtues. Some of my other works, as the white devil, the Duchess of Malfi, Guise, and others, you have formerly seen; I present this humbly to kiss your hands, and to find your allowance. Nor do I much doubt it, knowing the greatest of the Caesars, have cheerfully entertained less poems than this: and had I thought it unworthy, I had not inquired after so worthy a patronage. Yourself I understand, to be all courtesy. I doubt not therefore of your acceptance, but resolve, that my election is happy. For which favour done me, I shall ever rest

closer.signed: Your worships humbly devoted, John Webster.

div.head: To the judicious reader.
div.p: I hold it, in these kind of poems with that of Horace, sapientia prima, stultitia caruisle; to be free from those vices, which proceed from ignorance; of which I take it, this play will ingeniously acquit itself. I do chief therefore expose it to the judicious: locus est, et pluribus umbris, others have leave to sit down, and read it, who come unbidden. But to these, should a man present them with the most excellent music, it would delight them no more, than auriculas citherae collecta sorde dolentes. I will not further insist upon the approvement of it, for I am so far from praising myself, that I have not given way to divers of my friends, whose unbegged commendatory verses offered themselves to do me service in the front of this poem. A great part of the grace of this (I confess) lay in action; yet can no action ever be gracious, where the decency of the language, and ingenious structure of the scene, arrive not to make up a perfect harmony. What I have failed of this, you that have approved my other works, (When you have read this) tax me of. For the rest, non ego ventosae plebis, suffragia venor.

div.head: The devil's law case. Or, when women go to law, the devil is full of business.

sp.speaker: Prospero.
sp.l: Ye have shown a world of wealth;
I did not think there had been a merchant
Lived in Italy of half your substance.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I'll give the King of Spain
Ten thousand ducats yearly, and discharge
My yearly custom. The Hollanders scarce trade
More generally than I: my factor's wives
Wear chaperones of velvet, and my scriveners
Merely through my employment, grow so rich,
They build their palaces and belvidears
With musical waterworks: never in my life
Had I a loss at sea. They call me on th'exchange,
The fortunate young man and make great suit
To venture with me: shall I tell you sir,
Of a strange confidence in my way of trading,
I reckon it as certain as the gain
In erecting a lottery.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I pray sir, what do you think
Of signior Baptisto's estate?

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: A mere beggar :
He's worth some fifty thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Is not that well?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How well? for a man to be melted to snow water,
with toiling in the world from three and twenty,
Till threescore for poor fifty thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: To your estate 'tis little I confess:
You have the springtide of gold.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Faith, and for silver,
Should I not send it packing to th'east Indies,
We should have a glut on't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here's the great lord Contarino.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O, I know his business, he's a suitor to your sister.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yes sir, but to you,
As my most trusted friend, I utter it,
I will break the alliance.

sp.speaker: Pros
sp.l: You are ill advised then;
There lives not a completer gentleman
In Italy, nor of a more ancient house.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What tell you me of gentry, 'tis naught else
But a superstitious relic of time passed:
And sift it to the true worth, it is nothing
But ancient riches: and in him you know
They are pitifully in the wane; he makes his colour
Of visiting us so often, to sell land,
And thinks if he can gain my sister's love,
To recover the treble value.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Sure he loves her entirely, and she deserves it.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Faith, though she were
Crooked shouldered, having such a portion,
She would have noble suitors; but truth is,
I would wish my noble venturer take heed,
It may be whiles he hopes to catch a gilt head,
He may draw up a gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Pros
sp.l: He's come: sir, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I sent you the evidence of the piece of land
I motioned to you for the sale.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Has your counsel perused it?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not yet my lord: do you intend to travel?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O then you lose
That which makes man most absolute.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Yet I have heard of divers, that in passing of the
Alps, have but exchanged their virtues at dear rate for other vices.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O my lord, lie not idle;
The chiefest action for a man of great spirit,
Is never to be out of action: we should think
The soul was never put into the body,
Which has so many rare and curious pieces
Of mathematical motion, to stand still.
Virtue is ever sowing of her seeds:
In the trenches for the soldier; in the wakeful study
For the scholar; in the sorrows of the sea
For men of our profession, of all which
Arise and spring up honour. Come, I know
You have some noble great design in hand,
That you levy so much money.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Sir, I'll tell you,
The greatest part of it I mean to employ
In payment of my debts, and the remainder
Is like to bring me into greater bonds, as I aim it.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: I intend it for the charge of my wedding.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Are you to be married, my lord?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Yes sir; and I must now entreat your pardon,
That I have concealed from you a business,
Wherein you had at first been called to counsel,
But that I thought it a less fault in friendship,
To engage myself thus far without your knowledge,
Then to do it against your will: another reason
Was, that I would not publish to the world,
Nor have it whispered scarce, what wealthy voyage
I went about, till I had got the mine
In mine own possession.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are dark to me yet,

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I'll now remove the cloud. Sir, your sister and I
Are vowed each others, and there only wants
Her worthy mothers, and your fair consents
To style it marriage: this is a way,
Not only to make a friendship, but confirm it
for our posterities. How do you look upon't?

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: Believe me sir, as on the principal column
To advance our house: why you bring honour with you,
Which is the soul of wealth. I shall be proud
To live to see my little nephews ride
O'th upper hand of their uncles; and the daughters
Be ranked by heralds at solemnities
Before the mother: all this derived
From your nobility. Do not blame me sir,
If I be taken with't exceedingly:
For this same honour with us citizens,
Is a thing we are mainly fond of, especially
When it comes without money, which is very seldom,
But as you do perceive my present temper,
Be sure I am yours, fired with scorn and laughter,
At your over confident purpose, and no doubt,
My mother will be of your mind.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: 'Tis my hope sir.
I do observe how this Romelio,
Has very worthy parts, were they not blasted
By insolent vain glory: there rests now
The mother's approbation to the match,
Who is a woman of that state and bearing,
Though she be city-born, both in her language,
Her garments, and her table, she excels
Our ladies of the court: she goes not gawdy,
Yet have I seen her wear one diamond,
Would have bought twenty gay ones out of their clothes,
And some of them, without the greater grace,
Out of their honesties.
She comes, I will try
How she stands affected to me, without relating
My contract with her daughter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, you are nobly welcome, and presume
You are in a place that's wholly dedicated
To your service.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am ever bound to you for many special favours.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, your fame renders you most worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: It could never have got a sweeter air to fly in,
Than your breath.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You have been strange a long time, you are weary
Of our unseasonable time of feeding:
Indeed th' exchange bell makes us dine so late;
I think the ladies of the court from us
Learn to lie so long a-bed .

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: They have a kind, of exchange among them too,
Marry unless, it be to hear of news, I take it,
Theirs, is like the new burse, thinly furnished
With Tyers and new fashions. I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I would not have you value it the less,
If I say, 'tis granted already.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: You are all bounty, 'tis to bestow your
Picture on me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O sir, shadows, are coveted in summer,
And with me, 'tis fall o'th leaf.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: You enjoy the best of time;
This latter spring of yours, shows in my eye,
More fruitful and more temperate withal,
Then that whose date is only limited
By the music of the cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed sir, I dare tell you,
My looking-glass is a true one, and as yet
It does not terrify me. Must you have my picture?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: So please you lady, and I shall preserve it
As a most choice object.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You will enjoin me to a strange punishment:
With what a compeld face a woman sits
While she is drawing? I have noted divers,
Either to feign smiles, or suck in the lips,
To have a little mouth; ruffle the cheeks,
To have the dimple seen, and so disorder
The face with affectation, at next sitting
It has not been the same; I have known others
Have lost the entire fashion of their face,
In half an hours sitting.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: In hot weather,
The painting on their face has been so mellow,
They have left the poor man harder work by half,
To mend the copy he wrought by #: but indeed,
If ever I would have mine drawn to'th life,
I would have a painter steal it, at such a time,
I were devoutly kneeling at my prayers,
There is then a heavenly beauty in't, the soul
Moons in the superficies.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Excellent lady,
Now you teach beauty a preservative,
More than 'gainst fading colours; and your judgement
Is perfect in all things.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed sir, I am a widow,
And want the addition to make it so:
For man's experience has still been held
Woman's best eyesight. I pray sir tell me,
You are about to sell a piece of land
To my son, I hear.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: 'Tis truth.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Now I could rather wish,
That noble men would ever live ith' country,
Rather than make their visits up to'th city
About such business: o sir, noble houses
Have no such goodly prospects any way,
As into their own land: the decay of that,
Next to their begging churchland, is a ruin
Worth all men's pity. Sir, I have forty thousand crowns
Sleep in my chest, shall waken when you please,
And sly to your commands, will you stay supper?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: I cannot, worthy lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I would not have you come hither sir, to sell,
But to settle your estate. I hope you understand
Wherefore I make this proffer: so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: What a treasury have I parched.
I hope you understand wherefore I make this proffer.
She has got some intelligence, how I intend to marry
Her daughter, and ingenuously perceived,
that by her picture, which I begged of her,
I meant the fair Jolenta: here's a letter,
Which gives express charge, not to visit her
Till midnight: fail not to come, for 'tis a business
That concerns both our honours.
Yours in danger to be lost, Jolenta.
'Tis a strange injunction; what should be the business?
She is not changed I hope. I'll thither straight:
For women's resolutions in such deeds,
Like bees, light oft on flowers, and oft on weeds.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: O sister come, the tailor must to work,
To make your wedding clothes.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: The tomb-maker, to take measure of my cousin.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Tomb-maker? look you,
The King of Spain greets you.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: What does this mean, do you serve process on me?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Process? come you would be witty now.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Why, what's this, I pray?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Infinite grace to you ▪ it is a letter
From his Catholic majesty, for the commends
Of this gentleman for your husband.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: In good season: I hope he will not have my
Allegiance stretched to the undoing of myself.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Undo yourself? he does proclaim him here

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Not for a traitor, does he?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are not mad;
For one of the noblest gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Yet Kings many times
Know merely but men's outsides, was this commendation
Voluntary, think you?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Voluntary: what mean you by that?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Why I do not think but he begged it of the King,
And it may fortune to be out of's way:
Some better suit, that would have stood his lordship
In far more stead: letters of commendations,
Why 'tis reported that they are grown stale,
when places fall i'th university.
I pray you return his pass: for to a widow
That longs to be a courtier, this paper
May do knights service.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Mistake not excellent mistress, these commends
Express, his majesty of Spain has given me
Both addition of honour, as you may perceive
By my habit, and a place here to command
O'er thirty galleys; this your brother shows,
As wishing that you would be partner
In my good fortune.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I pray come hither, have I any interest in you?

sp.speaker: Jol
sp.l: You are my brother.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I would have you then use me with that respect,
You may still keep me so, and to be swayed
In this main business of life, which wants
Greatest consideration, your marriage,
By my direction: here's a gentleman —

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Sir, I have often told you,
I am so little my own to dispose that way,
That I can never be his.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Come, too much light
Makes you moon-eyed, are you in love with title?
I will have a herald, whose continual practice
Is all in pedigree, come a-wooing to you,
Or an antiquary in old buskins.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Sir, you have done me
The mainest wrong that ere was offered
To a gentleman of my breeding.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: You have led me
With a vain confidence, that I should marry
Your sister, have proclaimed it to my friends,
Employed the greatest lawyers of our state
To settle her a jointure, and the issue
Is, that I must become ridiculous
Both to my friends and enemies: I will leave you,
Till I call to you for a strict account
Of your unmanly dealing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Stay my lord.
Do you long to have my throat cut? Good my lord,
Stay but a little, till I have removed
This court-mist from her eyes, till I wake her
From this dull sleep, wherein she'll dream herself
To a deformed beggar: you would marry
The great lord Contarino.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Contarino
Were you talking of? he lost last night at dice
Five thousand ducats; and when that was gone,
Set at one throw a lordship, that twice trebled
The former loss.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And that flew after.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And most carefully
Carried the gentleman in his caroche
To a lawyer's chamber, there most legally
To put him in possession: was this wisdom?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O yes, their credit in the way of gaming
Is the main thing they stand on, that must be paid,
Though the brewer bawl for's money; and this lord
Does she prefer i'th way of marriage,
Before our choice. Here noble Ercole,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You'll be advised I hope: know for your sakes
I married, that I might have children;
And for your sakes, if you'll be ruled by me,
I will never marry again. Here's a gentleman
Is noble, rich, well featured, but 'bove all,
He loves you entirely; his intents are aimed
For an expedition 'gainst the Turk,
Which makes the contract cannot be delayed.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Contract? you must do this without my knowledge;
Give me some potion to make me mad,
And happily not knowing what I speak,
I may then consent to't.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Come, you are mad already,
And I shall never hear you speak good sense,
Till you name him for husband.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Lady, I will do a manly office for you,
I will leave you, to the freedom of your own soul,
may it move whither heaven and you please.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Now you express yourself most nobly.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Stay sir, what do you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hear me, if thou dost marry Contarino,
All the misfortune that did ever dwell.
In a parent's curse, light on thee.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: O rise lady, certainly heaven never intended
Kneeling to this fearful purpose.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Your imprecation has undone me for ever.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Give't rue then:
O what rare workmanship have I seen this
To finish with your needle, what excellent music
Have these struck upon the viol!
Now I'll teach a piece of art.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Rather a damnable cunning,
To have me go about to give't away,
Without consent of my soul.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Kiss her my lord, if crying had been regarded,
Maidenheads had ne'er been lost, at least some appearance
Of crying, as an April shower i'th sunshine.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She is yours.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Nay, continue your station, and deal you in dumb show; kiss this doggedness out of her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To be contracted in tears, is but fashionable.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yet suppose that they were hearty.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Virgin's must seem unwilling.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O what else; and you remember, we observe the
Like in greater ceremonies than these contracts,
At the consecration of prelates, they use ever
Twice to say nay, and take it.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: O brother.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Keep your possession, you have the door bithring,
That's livery and season in England; but my lord,
Kiss that tear from her lip, you'll find the rose
The sweeter for the dew.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: Bitter as gall.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ay, ay, all you women,
Although you be of never so low stature,
Have gall in you most abundant, it exceeds
Your brains by two ounces. I was saying somewhat;
O do but observe ith' city, and you'll find
The thriftiest bargains that were ever made,
What a deal of wrangling ere they could be brought
To an upshot.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Great persons do not ever come together.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: With revelling faces, nor is it necessary
They should; the strangeness and unwillingness
Wears the greater state, and gives occasion that
The people may buzz and talk of't, though the bells
Be tongue-tied at the wedding.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And truly I have heard say,
To be a little strange to one another,
Will keep your longing fresh.

sp.speaker: Rom,
sp.l: Ay, and make you beget
More children when you're married: some doctors
Are of that opinion. You see my lord, we are merry
At the contract, your sport is to come hereafter.

sp.speaker: Ercol.
sp.l: I will leave you excellent lady, and withal
Leave a heart with you so entirely yours,
That I protest, had I the least of hope
To enjoy you, though I were to wait the time
That scholars do in taking their degree
In the noble arts, 'twere nothing, howsoe'er
He parts from you, that will depart from life,
To do you any service, and so humbly
I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Sir, I will pray for you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Why that's well, 'twill make your prayer complete,
To pray for your husband.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Husband?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This is the happiest hour that I ever arrived at.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Husband, I husband: come you peevish thing,
Smile me a thank for the pains I have ta'en.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: I hate myself for being thus enforced,
you may soon judge then what I think of you
Which are the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You lady of the laundry, come hither.

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Look as you love your life, you have an eye
Upon your mistress; I do henceforth bar her
All visitants: I do hear there are bawds abroad,
That bring cut-works, and man-toons, and convey letters
To such young gentlewomen, and there are others
That deal in corn-cutting, and fortune-telling,
Let none of these come at her on your life,
Nor dews ace the wafer woman, that prigs abroad
With muskmeloons, and malakatoones;
Nor the Scotchwoman with the cittern, do you mark,
Nor a dancer by any means, though he ride on's foot-cloth,
Nor a hackney coachman, if he can speak French.

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By no means: no more words;
Nor the woman with marrowbone puddings. I have heard
Strange juggling tricks have been conveyed to a woman
In a pudding: you are apprehensive?

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: O good sir, I have travelled.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: When you had a bastard, you travelled indeed:
But my precious chaperones,
I trust thee the better for that; for I have heard,
There is no warier keeper of a park,
To prevent stalkers, or your night-walkers,
Than such a man, as in his youth has been
A most notorious deer-stealer.

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: Very well sir,
You may use me at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By no means Winifrid, that were the way
To make thee travel again: come be not angry,
I do but jest, thou knowest, wit and a woman,
Are two very frail things, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: I could weep with you, but 'tis no matter,
I can do that at any time, I have now
a greater mind to rail a little: plague of these
Unsanctified matches; they make us loath
The most natural desire our grandam Eve ever left us.
Force one to marry against their will; why 'tis
A more ungodly work, then enclosing the commons.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: Prithee peace;
This is indeed an argument so common,
I cannot think of matter new enough,
To express it bad enough,

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: Here's one I hope will put you out of't.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: How now sweet mistress?
You have made sorrow look lovely of late,
You have wept.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: She has done nothing else these three days; had you stood behind the arras, to have heard her shed so much salt water as I have done, you would have thought she had been turned fountain.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I would fain know the cause can be worthy this
Thy sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Reach me the caskanet, I am studying sir,
To take an inventory of all that's mine.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What to do with it lady?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: To make you a deed of gift.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That's done already; you are all mine.

sp.speaker: Wai.
sp.l: Yes, but the devil would fain put in for's share,
In likeness of a separation.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: O sir, I am bewitched.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Most certain, I am forespoken,
To be married to another: can you ever think
That I shall ever thrive in't? Am I not then bewitched?
All comfort I can teach myself is this,
There is a time left for me to die nobly,
When I cannot live so?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Give me in a word, to whom, or by whose means
Are you thus torn from me?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: By lord Ercole, my mother, and by brother.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: I'll make his bravery fitter for a grave,
Then for a wedding.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: So you will beget
A far more dangerous and strange disease
Out of the cure; you must love him again
For my sake: for the noble Ercole
Had such a true compassion of my sorrow.
Hark in your ear, he show you his right worthy
Demeanour to me.

sp.speaker: Wayt.
sp.l: O you pretty ones,
I have seen this lord many a time and oft
Set her in's lap, and talk to her of love
So feelingly, I do protest it has made me
Run out of myself to think on't; o sweet breathed
Monkey, how they grow together? well, 'tis my opinion,
He was no woman's friend that did invent
A punishment for kissing.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: If he bear himself so nobly,
The manliest office I can do for him,
Is to afford him my pity, since he's like
To fail of so dear a purchase: for your mother,
Your goodness quits her ill; for your brother,
He that vows friendship to a man, and proves
A traitor deserves rather to be hanged ,
Than he that counterfeits money; yet for your sake
I must sign his pardon too. Why do you tremble?
Be safe, you are now free from him.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: O but sir,
The intermission from a fit of an ague
Is grievous: for indeed it doth prepare us,
To entertain torment next morning.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Why he's gone to sea.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: But he may return too soon.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To avoid which, we will instantly be married.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: To avoid which, get you instantly to bed together,
Do, and I think no civil lawyer for his fee
Can give you better council.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Fie upon thee, prithee leave us.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Be of comfort sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: On one condition we may have no quarrel about

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Upon my life none. (This.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: None upon your honour?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With whom? with Ercole?
You have delivered him guiltless.
With your brother? He's part of yourself.
With your complemental mother?
I use not sight with women
Tomorrow we'll be married:
Let those that would oppose this union,
Grow never so subtle, and entangle themselves
In their own work like spiders, while we two
Haste to our noble wishes, and presume,
The hindrance of it will breed more delight,
As black copartaments shows gold more bright.

sp.speaker: Crisp
sp.l: Am I well habited?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Exceeding well; any man would take you for a merchant: but pray sir resolve me, what should be the reason, that you being one of the most eminent civil lawyers in Spain, and but newly arrived from the East Indies, should take this habit of a merchant upon you?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Why my son lives here in Naples and in's riot
Doth far exceed the exhibition I allowed him.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: So then, and in this disguise you mean to trace him.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Partly for that, but there is other business
Of greater consequence.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Faith for his expense, 'tis nothing to your estate, what to don Crispiano, the famous corregidor of civil, who by his mere practice of the law, in less time than half a jubilee, hath gotten thirty thousand ducats a year.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Well, I will give him line,
Let him run on in's course of spending.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Freely?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Freely:
For I protest, if that I could conceive
My son would take more pleasure or content,
By any course of riot, in the expense,
Than I took joy, nay soul's felicity
In the getting of it, should all the wealth I have
Waste to as small an atomy as flies
I'th'unne, I do protest on that condition,
It should not move me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: How's this? Cannot he take more pleasure in spending it riotously, than you have done by scraping it together: oh ten thousand times more, and I make no question, five hundred young gallants will be of my opinion.
sp.l: Why all the time of your collectionship,
Has been a perpetual Callender, begin first
With your melancholy study of the law
Before you come to singer the ruddocks, after that
The tiring importunity of clients,
To rise so early, and sit up so late,
You made yourself half ready in a dream,
And never prayed but in your sleep: can I think,
That you have half your lungs left with crying out
For judgements, and days of trial. Remember sir,
How often have I born you on my shoulder,
Among a shoal or swarm of reeking nightcaps,
When that your worship has bepissed yourself,
Either with vehemency of argument,
Or being out from the matter. I am merry.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Be so.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: You could eat like a gentleman, at leisure;
But swallow it like hap-dragons, as if you had lived
With chewing the cud after.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: No pleasure in the world was comparable to't.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Possible?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: He shall never taste the like, unless he study law.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What, not in wenching sir?
'Tis a court game, believe it,
As familiar as gleek, or any other.

sp.speaker: Crisp
sp.l: Wenching? O fie, the disease follows it:
Beside, can the fingring taffeties, or lawns,
Or a painted hand, or a breast be like the pleasure
In taking clients fees, and piling them
In several goodly rows before my desk?
And according to the bigness of each heap,
Which I took by a lere: for lawyers do not tell them,
I veiled my cap, and withal gave great hope
The cause should go on their sides.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What think you then
Of a good cry of hounds? It has been known
Dogs have hunted lordships to a fault.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Cry of curs?
The noise of clients at my chamber door,
Was sweeter music far, in my conceit,
Than all the haunting in Europe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Pray stay sir,
Say he should spend it in good housekeeping.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I marry sir, to have him keep a good house,
And not sell't away, I'd find no fault with that:
But his kitchen, I'd have no bigger than a saw-pit;
For the smallness of a kitchen without question,
Makes many noblemen in France and Spain,
Build the rest of the house the bigger.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes, mock-beggars.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Some seven-score chimneys,
But half of them have no tunnels.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A pox upon them cuckshawes that beget
Such monsters without fundaments.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Come, come, leave citing other vanities;
For neither wine, nor lust, nor riotous feasts,
Rich clothes, nor all the pleasure that the devil
Has ever practised with, to raise a man
To a devil's likeness, ere brought man that pleasure
I took in getting my wealth: so I conclude.
If he can outvie me, let it fly to'th devil.
Yon's my son, what company keeps he?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The gentleman he talks with,
Is Romelio the merchant.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I never saw him till now,
'A has a brave sprightly look, I knew his father,
And sojourned in his house two years together,
Before this young man's birth; I have news to tell him
Of certain losses happened him at sea,
That will not please him.

sp.speaker: San
sp.l: What that dapper fellow
In the long stocking? I do think 'twas he
Came to your lodging this morning.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: 'Tis the same,
There he stands, but a little piece of flesh,
But he is the very miracle of a lawyer,
One that persuades men to peace, and compounds quarrels
Among his neighbours, without going to law.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And is he a lawyer?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Yes, and will give counsel
In honest causes gratis, never in his life
Took fee, but he came and spoke for't, is a man
Of extreme practice, and yet all his longing,
Is to become a judge.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Indeed that's a rare longing with men of his profession. I think he'll prove the miracle of a lawyer indeed.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Here's the man brought word your father died i'th Indies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He died in perfect memory I hope,
And made me his heir.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He's gone the right way then without question:
Friend, in time of mourning, we must not use any action,
That is but accessary to the making men merry,
I do therefore give you nothing for your good tidings.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Nor do I look for it sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Honest fellow, give me thy hand, I do not think but thou hast carried new years gifts to'th court in thy days, and learnedst there to be so free of thy pains taking.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Here's an old gentleman says he was chamber-fellow to your father, when they studied the law together at Barcelona.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not I, he's newly come to Naples.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And what's his business?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: 'A says he's come to read you good counsel.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: To him, rate him soundly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And what's your counsel?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Why, I would have you leave your whoring.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He comes hotly upon me at first: whoring?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: O young quat, incontinence is plagued
In all the creatures of the world.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: When did you ever hear, that a cocksparrow
Had the French pox?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: When did you ever know any of them fat, but in the nest? ask all your cantaride-mongers that question; remember yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A very fine naturalist, a physician, I raise you by your round slop; for 'tis just of the bigness, and no more, of the case for a urinal: 'tis concluded, you are a physician. What do you mean sir, you'd take cold.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: 'Tis concluded, you are a fool, a precious one, you are a mere stick of sugar candy, a man may look quite thorough you

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You are a very bold gamester.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I can play at chess, and know how to handle a rook.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray preserve your velvet from the dust.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Keep your hat upon the block sir,
'Twill continue fashion the longer.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I was never so abused with the hat in the hand
In my life.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I will put on, why look you,
Those lands that were the clients, are now become
The lawyers; and those tenements that were
The country gentleman's, are now grown
To be his tailors.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tailors?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Yes, tailors in France, they grow to great
Abominable purchase, and become great officers.
How many ducats think you he has spent
Within a twelvemonth, besides his father's allowance?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Besides my father's allowance?
Why gentleman, do you think an auditor begat me?
Would you have me make even at years end?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: A hundred ducats a month in breaking Venice glasses.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: He learned that of an English drunkard,
And a knight too, as I take it.
This comes of your numerous wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ay, and wearing cutwork, a pound a pearl.

sp.speaker: Ario
sp.l: Your dainty embroidered stockings,
With overblown roses, to hide your gouty ankles.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And wearing more taffety for a garter, then would serve the galley dung-boat for streamers. (Strissimi.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Your switching up at the horse-race, with the illum -

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: And studying a puffing arithmetic at the cockpit.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Shaking your elbow at the taule-boord.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And resorting to your whore in hired velvet,
With a spangled copper fringe at her Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Whereas if you had stayed at Padua, and fed upon
Cow trotters, and fresh beef to supper.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How I am baited?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Nay, be not you so forward with him neither, for 'tis thought, you'll prove a main part of his undoing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I think this fellow is a witch

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Who I sir?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: You have certain rich city chuffs, that when they have no acres of their own, they will go and blow up fools, and turn them into excellent meadow; besides some enclosures for the first cherries in the spring,
And apricots to pleasure a friend at court with.

You have pothecaries deal in selling commodities to young gallants, will put four or five coxcombs into a sieve, and so drum with them upon their counter; they'll searse
them through like ginny pepper, they cannot endure to find a man like a pair of tarriers, they would undo him in a trice.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: May be there are such.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: O terrible exactors, fellows with six hands,
And three heads.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I those are hell hounds.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Take heed of them, they'll rent thee like tenterhooks. Hark in your ear, there is intelligence upon you; the report goes, there has been gold conveyed beyond the sea in hollow anchors. Farewell, you shall know me better, I will do thee more good, than thou art aware of.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He's a mad fellow.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: He would have made an excellent barber,
He does so curry it with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Sir, I was directed to you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: From the East Indies.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Please you walk apart,
I shall acquaint you with particulars
Touching your trading i'th East Indies.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Willingly, pray walk sir.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.p: O my right worthy friends, you have stayed me long, one health, and then aboard; for all the galleys are come about.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Signior Ercole,
The wind has stood my friend sir, to prevent
Your putting to sea.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Pray why sit?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Only love sir,
That I might take my leave sir, and withal
Entreat from you a private recommends
To a friend in Malta, 'twould be delivered
To your bosom, for I had no time to write.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Pray leave us gentlemen.
Will't please you sit?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, my love to you has proclaimed you one,
whose word was still led by a noble thought,
And that thought followed by as fair a died:
Deceive not that opinion, we were students
At Padua together, and have long
To'th world's eye shown like friends,
Was it hearty on your part to me?

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Unfeigned.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You are false
To the good thought I held of you, and now
Join the worst part of man to you, your malice,
To uphold that falsehood, sacred innocence
Is fled your bosom. Signior, I must tell you,
To draw the picture of unkindness truly,
Is to express two that have dear loved,
And fallen at variance; 'tis a wonder to me,
Knowing my interest in the fair Jolenta,
That you should love her.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Compare her beauty, and my youth together,
And you will find the fair effects of love
No miracle at all.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: Yes, it will prove prodigious to you.
I must stay your voyage.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Your warrant must be mighty.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Thas a seal from heaven
To do it, since you would ravish from me
What's there entitled mine: and yet I vow,
By the essential front of spotless virtue,
I have compassion of both our youths:
To approve which, I have not ta'en the way,
Like an Italian, to cut your throat
By practice, that had given you now for dead,
And never frowned upon you.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: You deal fair sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Quit me of one doubt, pray sir.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Move it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis this,
Whether her brother were a main instrument
In her design for marriage.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: If I tell truth, you will not credit me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I will tell you truth,
Yet show some reason you have not to believe me:
Her brother had no hand in't, is't not hard
For you to credit this: for you may think,
I count it baseness to engage another
Into my quarrel; and for that take leave
To dissemble the truth. Sir, if you will fight
With any but myself, fight with her mother,
She was the motive.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have no enemy in the world then, but yourself;
You must fight with me.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And instantly.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I will haste before you, point whither.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: Why you speak nobly, and for this fair dealing,
Were the rich jewel which we vary for,
A thing to be divided, by my life,
I would be well content to give you half:
But since 'tis vain to think we can be friends,
'Tis needful one of us be ta'en away,
From being the others enemy.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Yet methinks , this looks not like a quarrel.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Not a quarrel?

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: You have not apparelled your fury well,
It goes too plain like a scholar.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: It is an ornament makes it more terrible,
And you shall find it
A weighty injury, and attended on
By discreet valour; because I do not strike you,
Or give you the lie, such foul preparatives
Would show like the stale injury of wine.
I reserve my rage to sit on my sword's point,
Which a great quantity of your best blood
Cannot satisfy.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: You promise well to yourself.
Shall's have no seconds?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: None, for fear of prevention.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: The length of our weapons.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: We'll sit them by the way:
So whether our time calls us to live or die,
Let us do both like noble gentlemen,
And true Italians.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: For that let me embrace you:

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Methinks , being an italian, I trust you
To come somewhat too near me:
But your jealousy gave that embrace to try
If I were armed, did it not.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: No believe me,
I take your heart to be sufficient proof,
Without a privy coat; and for my part,
A taffety is all the shirt of mail
I am armed with.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: You deal equally.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where are these gallants, the brave Ercole,
And noble Contarino?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: They are newly gone sir,
And bade me tell you, that they will return
Within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Met you the lord Ercole?

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: No, but I met the devil in villainous tidings.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O I am poured out like water, the greatest
Rivers i'th world are lost in the sea,
And so am I: pray leave me.
Where's lord Ercole?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You were scarce gone hence, but in came Contarino.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Contarino?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And entreated some private conference with Ercole,
And on the sudden they have giv'n's the slip.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: One mischief never comes alone:
They are gone to fight.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To fight?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And you be gentlemen,
Do not talk, but make haste after them.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let's take several ways then,
And if't be possible for women's sakes,
For they are proper men, use our endeavours,
That the prick do not spoil them.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You'll not forgo your interest in my mistress?

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: My sword shall answer that; come, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Before you fight sir, think upon your cause,
It is a wondrous foul one, and I wish,
That all your exercise these four days past,
Had been employed in a most fervent prayer,
And the foul sin for which you are to fight
Chiefly remembered in't.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I'd as soon take
Your counsel in divinity at this present,
As I would take a kind direction from you
For the managing my weapon; and indeed,
Both would show much alike.
Come are you ready?

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: Bethink yourself,
How fair the object is that we contend for.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: O, I cannot forget it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You are hurt.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Did you come hither only to tell me so,
Or to do it? I mean well, but 'twill not thrive.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Your cause, your cause sir:
Will you yet be a man of conscience, and make
Restitution for your rage upon your deathbed?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Never, till the grave gather one of us.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That was fair, and home I think.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You prate as if you were in a fence-school.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Spare your youth, have compassion on yourself.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: When I am all in pieces, I am now unfit
For any lady's bed; take the rest with you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am lost in too much daring: yield your sword.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: To the pangs of death I shall, but not to thee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You are now at my repairing, or confusion:
beg your life.

sp.speaker: Erc
sp.l: O most foolishly demanded,
To bid me beg that which thou canst not give.
sp.stage: Enter Romelio, Prosp. Bapt. Ario Julio.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: See both of them are lost; we come too late.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Take up the body, and convey it
To saint Sebastian's monastery.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I will not part with his sword, I have won't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You shall not:
Take him up gently: so, and bow his body,
For fear of bleeding inward.
Well, these are perfect lovers.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Why, I pray?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It has been ever my opinion,
That there are none love perfectly indeed,
But those that hang or drown themselves for love:
Now these have chose a death next to beheading,
They have cut one another's throats,
Brave valiant lads.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Come, you do ill, to set the name of valour
Upon a violent and mad despair.
Hence may all learn, that count such actions well,
The roots of fury shoot themselves to hell.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Your losses I confess, are infinite,
Yet sir, you must have patience.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Sir, my losses I know, but you I do not.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: 'Tis most true, I am but a stranger to you, but am
Wished by some of your best friends, to visit you,
And out of my experience in the world,
To instruct you patience.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Of what profession are you?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Sir, I am a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Of all men living,
You lawyers I account the only men
To confirm patience in us, your delays
Would make three parts of this little Christian world
Run out of their wits else.
Now I remember, you read lectures to Julio,
are you such a leech for patience?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Yes sir, I have had some crosses.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are married then I am certain.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: That I am sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And have you studied patience?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: You shall find I have.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Did you ever see your wife make you cuckold?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Make me cuckold?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I ask it seriously, and you have not seen that,
Your patience has not ta'en the right degree
Of wearing scarlet; I should rather take you
For a bachelor in the art, then for a doctor.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: You are merry. (Angry.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No sir, with leave of your patience, I am horrible

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What should move you?
Put forth that harsh interrogatory, if these eyes
Ever saw my wife do the thing you wot of.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why I'll tell you,
Most radically to try your patience,
And the mere question shows you but a dunce in't.
It has made you angry; there's another lawyer's beard
In your forehead, you do bristle.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: You are very conceited:
But come, this is not the right way to cure you.
I must talk to you like a divine.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: I have heard some talk of it very much, and many
Times to their auditor's impatience; but I pray,
What practice do they make of't in their lives?
They are too full of choler with living honest,
And some of them not only impatient
Of their own sleightest injuries, but stark mad,
At one another's preferment: now to you sir,
I have lost three goodly carracks.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: So I hear.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The very spice in them,
Had they been shipwrecked here upon our coast,
Would have made all our sea a drench.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: All the sick horses in Italy
Would have been glad of your loss them.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are conceited too,

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Come, come, come,
You gave those ships most strange, most dreadful,
And unfortunate names, I never looked they'd prosper.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is there any ill omen in giving names to ships?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Did you not call one, the storms defiance;
Another, the scourge of the sea; and the third, the great Leviathan?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Very right sir.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Very devilish names
All three of them: and surely I think,
They were cursed in their very cradles, I do mean,
When they were upon their stocks.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Come, you are superstitious,
I'll give you my opinion, and 'tis serious:
I am persuaded there came not cuckolds enough
To the first launching of them,
And 'twas that made them thrive the worse for't.
O your cuckold's handsel is prayed for i'th city.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I will hear no more,
Give me thy hand, my intent of coming hither,
Was to persuade you to patience; as I live,
If ever I do visit you again,
It shall be to entreat you to be angry, sure I will,
I'll be as good as my word, believe it.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So sir: how now?
Are the screech-owls abroad already?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What a dismal noise yond bell makes,
Sure some great person's dead.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No such matter,
It is the common bellman goes about,
To publish the sale of goods.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why do they ring before my gate thus?
Let them into'th court, I cannot understand
What they say.
sp.stage: Enter two belmen and a capouchin.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: For pity's sake, you that have tears to shed,
Sigh a soft requiem, and let fall a bead,
For two unfortunate nobles, whose sad fate
Leaves them both dead, and excommunicate:
No churchman's prayer to comfort their last groans,
no sacred seed of earth to hide their bones;
But as their fury wrought them out of breath,
The cannon speaks them guilty of their own death.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What noble men I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The lord Ercole, and the noble Contarino,
Both of them slain in single combat.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O, I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Denied Christian burial, I pray what does that,
Or the dead lazy march in the funeral,
Or the flattery in the epitaphs, which shows
More sluttish far than all the spider's webs
Shall ever grow upon it: what do these
Add to our well being after death?

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: Not a scruple.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Very well then,
I have a certain meditation,
If I can think of somewhat to this purpose,
I'll say it to you, while my mother there
Numbers her beads.
You that dwell near these graves and vaults,
Which oft do hide physician's faults,
Note what a small room does suffice,
To express men's good, their vanities,
Would fill more volume in small hand,
Than all the evidence of churchland.
Funerals hide men in civil wearing,
And are to the drapers a good hearing,
Make the heralds laugh in their black payment,
And all die worthies die worth payment.
To the altar offerings, though their fame,
And all the charity of their name,
Between heaven and this yield no more light,
Then rotten trees, which shine i'th night.
O look the last act be the best i'th play,
And then rest gentle bones, yet pray,
That when by the precise you are viewed,
A supersede as be not sued,
To remove you to a place more airy,
that in your stead they may keep chary
Stockfish, or seacole, for the abuses
Of sacrilege have turned graves to vilder uses.
How then can any monument say,
Here rest these bones, till the last day,
When time swift both of foot and feather,
May bear them the sexton kens not whither.
What care I then, though my last sleep,
Be in the desert, or in the deep,
No lamp, nor taper, day and night,
To give my charnel chargeable light:
I have there like quantity of ground,
And at the last day I shall be found.
Now I pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: I am sorry for your losses.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Umh sir the more spacious that the tennis court is,
The more large is the hazard.
I dare the spiteful fortune do her worst,
I can now fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: O sir, yet consider,
He that is without fear, is without hope,
And sins from presumption; better thoughts attend you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Poor Jolenta, should she hear of this?
She would not after the report keep fresh,
So long as flowers in graves.
How now Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Contarino has sent you here his will,
Wherein a has made your sister his sole heir.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: Is he not dead?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He's yet living.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Living? the worse luck.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The worse: I do protest it is the best,
That ever came to disturb my prayers.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yet I would have him live
To satisfy public justice for the death
Of Ercole: o go visit him for heaven's sake.
I have within my closet a choice relic,
Preservative 'gainst swooning, and some earth,
brought from the holy land, right sovereign
To staunch blood: has he skilful surgeons, think you?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The best in Naples?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How oft has he been dressed?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But once.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I have some skill this way:
The second or third dressing will show clearly,
Whether there be hope of life: I pray be near him,
If there be any soul can bring me word,
That there is hope of life.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Do you prize his life so?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That he may live;
I mean to come to his trial , to satisfy the law.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O, is't nothing else?

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.l: I shall be the happiest woman.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Here is cruelty apparelled in kindness.
I am full of thoughts, strange ones, but they're no good ones.
I must visit Contarino, upon that
Depends an engine shall weigh up my losses,
Were they sunk as low as hell; yet let me think,
How I am impaired in a hour, and the cause of't,
Lost in security: o how this wicked world bewitches,
Especially made insolent with riches:
So sails with fore-winds stretched, do soonest break,
And pyramids ath' top, are still most weak.
sp.stage: Enter Capuchin, Ercole led between two.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Look up sir, you are preserved beyond natural reason, you were brought dead out a'th field, the surgeons ready to have embalmed you.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I do look on my action with a thought of terror,
To do ill and dwell in't, is unmanly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You are divinely informed sir.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I fought for one, in whom I have no more right,
Then false executors have in orphans goods,
They cozen them of; yet though my cause were naught,
I rather chose the hazard of my soul,
Then forego the compliment of a choleric man.
I pray continue the report of my death, and give out,
Cause the church denied me Christian burial,
The vice admiral of my galleys took my body,
With purpose to commit it to the earth,
Either in Sicil, or Malta.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What aim you at by this rumour of your death?

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: There is hope of life
In Contarino; and he has my prayers,
That he may live to enjoy what is his own,
The fair Jolenta; where, should it be thought
That I were breathing, happily her friends
Would oppose it still.

sp.speaker: Capu.
sp.l: But if you be supposed dead,
The law will strictly prosecute his life
For your murder.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: That's prevented thus,
There does belong a noble privilege
To all his family, ever since his father,
Bore from the worthy emperor Charles the fifth,
An answer to the French Kings challenge, at such time
The two noble princes were engaged to fight.
Upon a frontier arm o'th sea in a flat-bottomed boat,
That if any of his family should chance
To kill a man i'th field, in a noble cause,
He should have his pardon; now sir, for his cause,
The world may judge if it were not honest.
Pray help me in speech, 'tis very painful to me.

sp.speaker: Capu
sp.l: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: The guilt of this lies in Romelio,
And as I hear, to second this good contract,
He has got a nun with child.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: These are crimes that either must make work
For speedy repentance, or for the devil.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I have much compassion on him,
For sin and shame are ever tied together,
With Gordian knots, of such a strong thread spun,
They cannot without violence be undone.

sp.speaker: Ariost.
sp.l: Well sir, now I must claim your promise,
To reveal to me the cause why you live thus clouded.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Sir, the King of Spain
Suspects, that your Romelio here, the merchant
Has discovered some gold-mine to his own use,
In the West Indies, and for that employs me,
To discover in what part of Christendom
He vents this I reassure: besides, he is informed
What mad tricks has been played of late by ladies.

sp.speaker: Ari
sp.l: Most true, and I am glad the King has heard on't:
Why they use their lords, as if they were their wards;
And as your Dutchwomen in the Low-countries,
Take all and pay all, and do keep their husbands
So silly all their lives of their own estates,
That when they are sick, and come to make their will,
They know not precisely what to give away
From their wives, because they know not what they are
So hear should I repeat what factions, (Worth:
What batfowling for offices,
As you must conceive their game is all i'th' night,
What calling in question one another's honesties
Withal what sway they bear i'th viceroy's court,
You'd wonder at it:
'Twill do well shortly, can we keep them off
From being of our council of war.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Well, I have vowed,
That I will never sit upon the bench more,
Unless it be to curb the insolences.
Of these women.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Well, take it on my word then,
Your place will not long be empty.
sp.stage: Enter Romelio in the habit of a Jew.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Excellently well habited, why methinks ,
That I could play with mine own shadow now,
and be a rare italienated Jew;
To have as many several change of faces,
As I have seen carved upon on cherry-stone;
To wind about a man like rotten ivy,
Eat into him like quicksilver, poison a friend
With pulling but a loose hair from's beard, or give a drench,
He should singer of't nine years, and ne'er complain,
But in the spring and fall, and so the cause
Imputed to the disease natural, for sleight villainies,
As to coin money, corrupt ladies' honours,
Betray a town to'th Turk, or make a bonfire
A'th Christian navy, I could settle to't,
As if I had eat a politician,
And digested him to nothing but pure blood.
But stay, I lose myself, this is the house.
Within there.

sp.speaker: 1 surgeon
sp.l: Now sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are the men of art, that as I hear,
Have the lord Contarino under cure.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: Yes sir, we are his surgeons,
But he is passed all cure.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why, is he dead?

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: He is speechless sir, and we do find his wound
So festered near the vitals, all our art
By warm drinks, cannot clear th'impostumation,
And he's so weak, to make
By the orifice were present death to him.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: He has made a will I hear.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: And deputed Jolenta his heir.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: He has, we are witness to't.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: Has not Romelio been with you yet,
To give you thanks, and ample recompense
For the pains you have ta'en.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Listen to me gentlemen, so I protest,
If you will seriously mind your own good,
I am come about a business shall convey
I arge legacies from Contarino's will
To both of you.

sp.speaker: 2 surgeon
sp.l: How sir?
Why Rom. has the will, and in that he has given us nothing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I pray attend me: I am a physician.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: A physician? where do you practise?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: In Rome.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: O then you have store of patients.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Store? why look you, I can kill my ●o a month
And work but i'th forenoons: you will give me leave
To jest and be merry with you, but as I said,
All my study has been physic, I am sent
From a noble roman that is near a kin
To Contarino, and that ought indeed,
By the law of iliance, be his only heir,
To practise his good and yours.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: How, I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I can by an extraction which I have,
Though he were speechless, his eyes set in's head,
His pulses without motion, restore to him
For half an hour's space, the use of sense,
And perhaps a little speech: having done this,
If we can work him, as no doubt we shall,
To make another will, and therein assign
This gentleman his heir, I will assure you,
Fore I depart this house, ten thousand ducats,
And then we'll pull the pillow from his head,
And let him e'en go whither the religion sends him
That he died in.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: Will you give's ten thousand ducats?

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: Upon my Jewism.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: 'Tis a bargain sir, we are yours:
Here is the subject you must work on.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Well said, you are honest men,
And go to the business roundly: but gentlemen,
I must use my art singly.

sp.speaker: 1 surgeon
sp.l: O sir, you shall have all privacy,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And the doors locked to me.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: At your best pleasure.
Yet for all this, I will not trust this Jew.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: Faith, to say truth,
I do not like him neither, he looks like a rogue.
This is a fine toy fetch a man to life,
To make a new will, there's some trick in't.
I'll be near you Jew.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Excellent as I would wish: these credulous fools
Have given me freely what I would have bought
With a great deal of money. - softly, here's breath yet;
Now Ercole, for part of the revenge,
Which I have vowed for thy untimely death:
Besides, this politic working of my own,
That scorns precedent, why should this great man live,
And not enjoy my sister, as I have vowed
He never shall? O, he may alters will
Every new moon if he please; to prevent which,
I must put in a strong caveat. Come forth then
My desperate stiletto, that may be worn
In a woman's hair, and never discovered,
And either would be taken for a bodkin,
Or a curling iron at most; why 'tis an engine,
That's only fit to put in execution Barmotho pigs,
A most unmanly weapon,
That steals into a man's life he knows not how:
Oh great Caesar, he that passed the shock
Of so many armed pikes, and poisoned darts,
Swords, slings, and battleaxes, should at length
Sitting at ease on a cushion, come to die
By such a shoemaker's awl as this, his soul et forth
At a hole, no bigger than the incision
Made for a wheal: vos foot, I am horribly angry,
That he should die so scurvily: yet wherefore
Do I condemn thee thereof so cruelly?
Yet shake him by the hand, 'tis to express,
That I would never have such weapons used,
But in a plot like this, that's treacherous:
Yet this shall prove most merciful to thee,
For it shall preserve thee
From dying on a public scaffold, and withal
bring thee an absolute cure, thus.
So, 'tis done: and now for my escape.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: You rogue mountebank,
I will try whether your innards can endure
To be washed in scalding lead.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Hold, I turn christian.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: Nay prithee be a Jew still;
I would not have a christian be guilty
Of such a villainous act as this is.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I am Romelio the merchant.

sp.speaker: 1 surgeon
sp.l: Romelio! you have proved yourself
A cunning merchant indeed.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You may read why I came hither.

sp.speaker: 2 surgeon
sp.l: Yes, in a bloody Roman letter.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I did hate this man, each minute of his breath
Was torture to me.

sp.speaker: 1 surgeon
sp.l: Had you forborn this act, he had not lived
This two hours.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But he had died then,
And my revenge unsatisfied: here's gold;
Never did wealthy man purchase the silence
Of a terrible scolding wife at a dearer rate,
Than I will pay for yours: here's your earnest
In a bag of double ducats.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: Why look you sir, as I do weigh this business,
This cannot be counted murder in you by no means.
Why 'tis no more, then should I go and choke
An Irish man, that were three quarters drowned,
With powering usquebath in's throat.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You will be secret

sp.speaker: 1. Su.
sp.l: As your soul. (Then.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The West Indies shall sooner want gold, than you

sp.speaker: 2. sum
sp.l: That protestation has the music of the mint in't.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How unfortunately was I surprised, I have made myself a slave perpetually to these two beggars.

sp.speaker: 1. Su.
sp.l: Excellent; by this act he has made his estate ours.

sp.speaker: 2. Su.
sp.p: He presently grow a lazy surgeon, and ride on my foot-cloth; he fetch from him every eight days a policy for a hundred double ducats; if he grumble, I'll peach.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: But let's take heed he do not poison us.

sp.speaker: 2 surgeon
sp.l: O, I will never eat nor drink with him,
Without unicorn's horn in a hollow tooth.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: Did he not groan?

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: Is the wind in that door still?

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: Ha! come hither, note a strange accident:
His steel has lighted in the former wound,
And made free passage for the congealed blood;
Observe in what abundance it delivers the putrefaction.

sp.speaker: 2. Surgeon
sp.l: Methinks he fetches his breath very lively.

sp.speaker: 1. Surgeon
sp.l: The hand of heaven is in't,
That his intent to kill him should become
The very direct way to save his life

sp.speaker: 2 surgeon
sp.l: Why this is like one I have heard of in England,
Was cured a'th gout, by being racked i'th tower.
Well, if we can recover him, here's reward
On both sides: howsoever we must be secret.

sp.speaker: 1 surgeon
sp.l: We are tied to't,
When we cure gentlemen of foul diseases,
They give us so much for the cure, and twice as much,
That we do not blab on't. Come let's to work roundly,
Heat the lotion, and bring the searing.
sp.stage: A table set forth with two tapers, a death's head, a book, Jolenta in mourning, Romelio sits by her.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: Why do you grieve thus? take a looking-glass,
And see if this sorrow become you; that pale face
Will make men think you used some art before,
Some odious painting: contarino's dead.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: O that he should die so soon.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why, I pray tell me,
Is not the shortest fever the best? and are not bad plays
The worse for their length?

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: Add not to'th ill you've done
An odious slander; he stuck i'th eyes a'th court,
As the most choice jewel there.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O be not angry;
Indeed the court to well composed nature
adds much to perfection: for it is or should be,
As a bright crystal, mirror to the world,
To dress itself; but I must tell you sister,
If th' excellency of the place could have wrought salvation,
The devil had ne'er fallen from heaven; he was proud,
Leave us, leave us?
Come, take your seat again, I have a plot,
If you will listen to it seriously,
That goes beyond example, it shall breed
Out of the death of these two noble men,
The advancement of our house.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: O take heed, a grave is a rotten foundation.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Nay, nay, hear me.
'Tis somewhat indirectly, I confess:
But there is much advancement in the world,
That comes in indirectly. I pray mind me:
You are already made by absolute will,
Contarino's heir: now, if it can be proved,
That you have issue by lord Ercole,
I will make you inherit his land too.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: How's this? issue by him, he dead, and I a virgin!

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I know you would wonder how it could be done,
But I have laid the case so radically,
Not all the lawyers in Christendom,
Shall find any the least flaw in't: I have a mistress
Of the order of saint Clare, a beauteous nun,
Who being cloistered ere she knew the heat,
Her blood would arrive to, had only time enough
To repent, and idleness sufficient
To fall in love with me; and to be short,
I have so much disordered the holy order,
I have got this nun with child.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Excellent work made for a dumb midwife.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I am glad you grow thus pleasant.
Now will I have you presently give out,
That you are full two months quickened with child
By Ercole, which rumour can beget
No scandal to you, since we will affirm,
the precontract was so exactly done,
By the same words used in the form of marriage,
That with a little dispensation,
A money matter, it shall be registered
Absolute matrimony.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: So then I conceive you,
My conceived child must prove your bastard.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Right: for at such time
My mistress falls in labour, you must feign the like.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: 'Tis a pretty feat this, but I am not capable of it.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not capable?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: No for the thing you would have me counterfeit,
Is most essentially put in practice: nay, 'tis done,
I am with child already.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ha by whom?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: By Contarino, do not knit the brow,
The precontract shall justify it, it shall:
Nay, I will get some singular fine churchman,
Or though he be a plural one, shall affirm,
He coupled us together

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O misfortune!
Your child must then be reputed Ercole's.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Your hopes are dashed then, since your votaries issue
Must not inherit the land.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No matter for that,
So I preserve her fame. I am strangely puzzled:
Why, suppose that she be brought a-bed before you,
And we conceal her issue till the time
Of your delivery, and then give out,
That you have two at a birth, ha, wert not excellent?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: And what resemblance think you, would they have
To one another? Twins are still alike:
But this is not your aim, you would have your child
Inherit Ercole's land, — o my sad soul,
Have you not made me yet wretched enough,
But after all this frosty age in youth,
Which you have witched upon me, you will seek
To poison my fame.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: That's done already.

sp.speaker: Jol
sp.l: No sir, I did but feign it,
To a fatal purpose, as I thought.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What purpose?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: If you had loved or tendered my dear honour,
You would have locked your poniard in my heart,
When I named I was with child; but I must live
To linger out, till the consumption of my own
Sorrow kill me.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: This will not do; the devil has on the sudden furnished me with a rare charm, yet a most unnatural falsehood: no matter so 'twill take.
sp.l: Stay sister, I would utter to you a business,
But I am very loath: a thing indeed,
Nature would have compassionately concealed,
Till my mother's eyes be closed.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Pray what's that sir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You did observe,
With what a dear regard our mother tendered
The lord Contarino, yet how passionately
She sought to cross the match: why this was merely
To blind the eye o'th world; for she did know
That you would marry him, and he was capable
My mother doted upon him, and it was plotted
Cunningly between them, after you were married,
Living all three together in one house,
A thing I cannot whisper without horror:
Why, the malice scarce of devils would suggest,
Incontinence between them two.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: I remember since his hurt,
She has been very passionately enquiring,
After his health.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Upon my soul, this jewel,
With a piece of the holy cross in't, this relic,
sp.p: Valued at many thousand crowns, she would have sent him, lying upon his death bed.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Professing as you say,
Love to my mother: wherefore did he make
Me his heir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: His will was made afore he went to fight,
When he was first a suitor to you.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: To fight: o well remembered,
If he loved my mother, wherefore did he lose
His life in my quarrel?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: For the affront's sake, a word you understand not,
Because Ercole was pretended rival to him,
To clear your suspicion; I was gulled in't too:
Should he not have fought upon't,
He had undergone the censure of a coward.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: How came you by this wretched knowledge?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: His surgeon overheard it,
As he did sigh it out to his confessor,
Some half hour fore he died.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: I would have the surgeon hanged
For abusing confession, and for making me
So wretched by'th report. Can this be truth?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No, but direct falsehood,
As ever was banished the court: did you ever hear
Of a mother that has kept her daughter's husband
For her own tooth? He fancied you in one kind,
For his lust, and he loved
Our mother in another kind, for her money,
The gallants fashion right. But come, ne'er think on't,
Throw the foul to the devil that hatched it, and let this
Bury all ill that's in't, she is our mother.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: I never did find any thing ith' world,
Turn my blood so much as this: here's such a conflict,
Between apparent presumption, and unbelief,
That I shall die in't.
O, if there be another world i'th moon,
As some fantastics dream, I could wish all men,
The whole race of them, for their inconstancy,
Sent thither to people that. Why, I protest,
I now affect the lord Ercole's memory,
Better than the others.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But were Contarino living.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: I do call any thing to witness,
that the divine law prescribed us
To strengthen an oath, were he living and in health,
I would never marry with him.
Nay, since I have found the world
So false to me, I'll be as false to it;
I will mother this child for you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Most certainly it will be guile part of my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Rom
sp.l: O most assuredly, make you smile to think,
How many times ith' world lordships descend
To divers men, that might and truth were known
Be heir, for any thing belongs to'th flesh,
As well to the Turks richest eunuch.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: But do you not think
I shall have a horrible strong breath now.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: O, with keeping your counsel, 'tis so terrible foul,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Come, come, come,
You must leave these bitter flashes.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Must I dissemble dishonesty? you have divers
Counterfeit honesty: but I hope here's none
Will take exceptions; I now must practise
The art of a great bellied woman, and go fain
Their qualms and swoonings.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Eat unripe fruit, and oatmeal, to take away your colour.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Dine in my bed some two hours afternoon .

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And when you are up,
Make to your petticoat a quilted preface,
To advance your belly.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: I have a strange conceit now.
I have known some women when they were with child,
Have longed to beat their husbands: what if I,
To keep decorum, exercise my longing
Upon my tailor that way, and noddle him soundly,
He'll make the larger bill for't.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I'll get one shall be as tractable to't as stockfish.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: O my fantastical sorrow,
Cannot I now be miserable enough,
unless I wear a pied fool's coat:
Nay worse, for when our passions
Such giddy and uncertain changes breed,
We are never well, till we are mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So, nothing in the world could have done this,
But to beget in her a strong distaste
Of the lord Contarino: o jealousy,
How violent, especially in women,
How often has it raised the devil up in form of a law case!
My especial care must be, to nourish craftily this fiend,
'Tween the mother and the daughter, that the deceit
Be not perceived. My next task, that my sister,
After this supposed childbirth, be persuaded
To enter into religion: 'tis concluded,
She must never marry; so I am left guardian
To her estate: and lastly, that my two surgeons
Be waged to the East Indies: let them prate,
When they are beyond the line; the calenture,
Or the scurvy, or the Indian pox, I hope,
Will take order for their coming back.
O here's my mother: I ha' strange news for you,
My sister is with child.

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.l: I do look now for some great misfortunes
To follow: for indeed mischiefs,
Are like the visits of Franciscan friars,
They never come to pray upon us single.
In what estate left you Contarino?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Strange, that you can skip
From the former sorrow to such a question!
I'll tell you, in the absence of his surgeon,
My charity did that for him in a trice,
They would have done at leisure, and been paid for't.
I have killed him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am twenty years elder since you last opened your lips.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You have given him the wound you speak of,
Quite thorough your mother's heart.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I will heal it presently mother: for this sorrow
belongs to your error: you would have him live,
Because you think he's father of the child;
But Jolenta vows by all the rights of truth,
'Tis Ercole's: it makes me smile to think,
How cunningly my sister could be drawn
To the contract, and yet how familiarly
To his bed. Doves never couple
Without a kind of murmur.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O, I am very sick.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Your old disease, when you are grieved,
You are troubled with the mother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am rapt with the mother indeed,
That I ever bore such a son.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Pray tend my sister,
I am infinitely full of business.

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.l: Stay you will mourn for Contarino.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O by all means, 'tis fit, my sister is his heir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will make you chief mourner, believe it.
Never was woe like mine: o that my care,
And absolute study to preserve his life,
Should be his absolute ruin. Is he gone then?
